s.text: Preparation and crystal structure of the oxalato-bridged CrIII–AgI two-dimensional compound {Ag3(H2O)[Cr(dpa)(ox)2]3}n·2nH2O (dpa = 2,2′-dipyridylamine)

The reaction of the mononuclear complex [Cr(dpa)(ox)2]− (dpa = 2,2-dipyridylamine) with Ag+ in aqueous solution affords the two-dimensional compound {Ag3(H2O)[Cr(dpa)(ox)2]3}n·2nH2O (1) whose structure has been determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction.
Six crystallographically independent metal atoms (three chromium and three silver atoms) occur in 1.
The three [Cr(dpa)(ox)2]− units in 1 act as ligands towards the silver atoms through the two oxalate groups.

Each oxalate group acts as bridging ligand adopting five coordination modes: bis-bidentate, bis-bidentate/monodentate (outer), bis-bidentate/monodentate (inner), bidentate/bis-monodentate (outer) and bidentate/monodentate (outer).

The use of the [Cr(AA)(ox)2]− (AA = bidentate nitrogen donor) building block in the design of heterometallic species of different dimensionalities is discussed in the light of the available structural results.

The tris-chelated species [Cr(ox)3]3− (ox = oxalate dianion) is one of the best examples of illustrating the richness of the synthetic strategy of heterometallic species which is based on the use of complexes as ligands (the so-called building block approach).

Taking advantage of its stability and inertness together with its high negative charge and the presence of six oxalate–oxygen donors, oxalate-bridged heterometallic two- and three-dimensional (nD) anionic networks were obtained by several research groups in the last decade.
Curiously, their dimensionality is dependent on the nature of the countercation which is indeed the templating agent of the overall structure.

So, honeycomb 2D structures of formula Cat[MIIMIII(ox)3] result when Cat+ is either an organic countercation of the type XR4+ (X = N, P; R = aryl, alkyl) or an organometallic decamethylmetallocenium unit [A(Cp*)2]+ (A = Fe, Co; Cp* = pentamethylcyclopentadienyl), whereas the tris-chelated [B(bpy)3]2+ complex (bpy = 2,2′-bipyridine) affords chiral anionic 3D networks of formulae [MII2(ox)3]−, [MIMIII(ox)3]− and [MIIMIII(ox)3]−.

These nD systems are examples of polyfunctional molecular-based materials which in addition to their interesting magnetic properties, can exhibit electrical conductivity, predesigned chirality and non-linear optical activity.

In an attempt to design lower dimensionality oxalato-bridged heterometallic complexes, the [Cr(ox)3]3− precursor was transformed into the [Cr(AA)(ox)2]− species (AA = bidentate nitrogen donor) which is still anionic but having only two terminally bound oxalate ligands.
Its reaction with fully solvated metal ions or preformed complexes which are coordinatively unsaturated, has provided quite a large family of new oxalato-bridged heterometallic species.
The bimetallic layered compound of formula {Ag3(H2O)[Cr(dpa)(ox)2]3}n·2nH2O (1) is one of them and its preparation, and spectroscopic and structural characterization are presented here.

A thorough discussion of the different new topologies of the reported heterometallic assemblies obtained using the [Cr(AA)(ox)2]− precursor [AA = 2,2′-bipyridine (bpy), 2,2′-bipyrimidine (bpym), 1,10-phenanthroline (phen) and 2,2′-dipyridylamine (dpa)] as a ligand is carried out.
Lithium and silver perchlorates were purchased from commercial sources and used as received.
PPh4[Cr(dpa)(ox)2]·H2O was prepared as reported elsewhere.
Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were carried out using an EA 1108 CHNS-O elemental analyzer.
IR spectrum of 1 (4000–400 cm−1) was recorded on a Nicolet Avatar 360 FT-IR spectrometer with the sample prepared as a KBr pellet.
{Ag3(H2O)[Cr(dpa)(ox)2]3}n·2nH2O (1).
LiClO4 (1 mmol) was added to an aqueous suspension (20 cm3) of stoichiometric amounts of PPh4[Cr(dpa)(ox)2]·H2O (0.25 mmol) and AgClO4 (0.25 mmol).
After two hours under continuous stirring at room temperature, the white solid of PPh4ClO4 formed was filtered off and discarded.
Slow evaporation of the remaining purple solution in the darkness yielded single crystals of 1 as deep red cubes.
Anal.
Selected IR data (KBr/cm−1): 3250 m (N–H stretching), 1710 s, 1684 s, 1654 s [νas(CO)], 1381 s, 1345 m [νs(CO)] and 810 m [δ(OCO)].
A suitable crystal of complex 1 was mounted on a Bruker-Nonius KappaCCD diffractometer.
Orientation matrix and lattice parameters were obtained by least-squares refinement of the reflections obtained by a θ–χ scan (Dirax/lsq method).
Data were collected at 293(2) K using graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å).
A summary of the crystallographic data and structure refinement is given in Table 1.
The indices of data collection were −13 ≤ h ≤ 13, −15 ≤ k ≤ 14, −33 ≤ l ≤ 33.
Of the 14619 measured independent reflexions in the θ range 2.99–30.02°, 11283 have I ≥ 2 σ(I).
All the measured independent reflections were used in the analysis.
All calculations for data reduction, structure solution, and refinement were done by standard procedures (WINGX).
The structure was solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique on F2 using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs.
All dpa hydrogen atoms were set in calculated positions and refined as rigid groups; the hydrogen atoms of water molecules were not found.
The final Fourier-difference map showed maximum and minimum height peaks of 0.897 and −1.389 e Å−3.
The final geometrical calculations and the graphical manipulations were carried out with PARST97 and CRYSTAL MAKER programs, respectively.
Selected bond distances and angles for 1 are listed in Table 2.
The structure of 1 consists of layers containing [Cr(dpa)(ox)2]− anions and Ag+ cations linked by oxalato groups which grow in the ab-plane (Fig 1).
Hydrogen bonds involving all water molecules and several oxalate–oxygen atoms (Table 3) contribute to stabilize the structure and lead to a three-dimensional network.
There are six metal atoms which are crystallographically independent, three chromium [Cr(1), Cr(2) and Cr(3)] and three silver [Ag(1), Ag(2) and Ag(3)] atoms.

Each chromium atom is six coordinated (see Fig. 2) with two nitrogen atoms from a bidentate dpa ligand and four oxalate oxygen atoms from two different oxalate ligands, describing a distorted octahedral environment.
The Cr–N distances [2.034(3)–2.073(3) Å] are somewhat longer than the Cr–O ones [1.956(2)–1.980(3) Å] and their values agree well with those reported for previous [Cr(AA)(ox)2]− containing complexes.
The angles subtended at the chromium atoms by the dpa [86.67(11)–88.16(11)°] and ox [82.41(11)–82.76(10)] are in good agreement with those reported for the [Cr(dpa)(ox)2]− unit in other complexes.
Six (three) crystallographically independent oxalate (dpa) ligands are present in 1.

The oxalate ligands exhibit five different coordination modes: C(1)/C(2) acts as bidentate [at Cr(1)] and bis-monodentate [towards Ag(3a) and Ag(1c); (a) x − 1, y, z]; C(3)/C(4) and C(29)/C(30) act as bis-bidentate [towards Cr(1) and Ag(1e) and towards Cr(3) and Ag(1), respectively] and monodentate inner [at Ag(2d)] and outer [at Ag(3)]; C(15)/C(16) and C(17)/C(18) act as bis-bidentate [towards Cr(2) and Ag(3) and towards Cr(2) and Ag(2), respectively]; C(31)/C(32) acts as bidentate [towards Cr(3)] and monodentate outer [at Ag(2)].
C(1)/C(2), C(17)/C(18), C(31)/C(32) oxalate ligands are planar whereas the remaining ones deviates from planarity.
The values of the dihedral angle between the oxalate ligands are 83.87(8)° [at Cr(1)], 61.68(7)° [at Cr(2)] and 89.26(8)° [at Cr(3)].

Two sets of oxalate carbon–oxygen bond distances are observed, the longer ones belonging to the oxalate oxygen atoms bound to the chromium atoms [the ranges of the values for inner and peripheral C–O bonds are 1.277–1.295 Å and 1.215–1.228 Å, respectively].
Dpa molecules are coordinated to the chromium atoms as bidentate ligands, forming six-membered rings that exhibit a screw-boat conformation.

The pyridyl rings of dpa ligands are planar [maximum deviation is 0.036(4) at C(38)] as expected, whereas the dpa ligand as a whole deviates significantly from planarity: the dihedral angles between pyridyl rings of dpa are 21.47(11)° [at Cr(1)], 19.37(12)° [at Cr(2)] and 35.67(13)° [at Cr(3)].

Each [Cr(dpa)(ox)2]− unit acts as a ligand towards the silver atoms (see Fig. 2): [Cr(1)(dpa)(ox)2]− exhibits bidentate and tris-monodentate coordination modes, [Cr(2)(dpa)(ox)2]− acts as bis-bidentate ligand and [Cr(3)(dpa)(ox)2]− adopts bidentate and bis-monodentate coordination modes.
Ag(1) and Ag(3) atoms are penta-coordinated with five [Ag(1)] and four oxalate oxygen atoms and one water molecule [Ag(3)], building distorted square pyramidal geometries (Fig. 3).
Ag(2) is coordinated by four oxalate oxygen atoms forming a distorted tetrahedron.
Ag–O(ox) bond distances, vary in the ranges of 2.415(3)–2.577(3) Å [Ag(1)], 2.238(3)–2.514(3) Å [Ag(2)] and 2.438(3)–2.568(3) Å [Ag(3)], respectively.

The values of the angles subtended by chelating oxalate at the silver atoms are 67.02(9) and 67.55(9)° [O(7e)–Ag(1)–O(8e) and O(19)–Ag(1)–O(20)], 71.21(9)° [O(11)–Ag(2)–O(12)] and 69.30(9)° [O(16)–Ag(3)–O(15)].
Decagon non-planar and centrosymmetric bimetallic cycles arising from the arrangement of [Cr(dpa)(ox)2]− and Ag+ cations are present in each layer of 1 (see Fig. 4).

Dpa groups and the coordinated [O(1w)] and one of the crystallization water molecules [O(3w)] are located outsite these cycles, whereas the remaining non-coordinated water molecule [O(2w)] is inside them.

Each metallocycle is linked to other four ones (see Fig. 4 and 5), through two tetranuclear Ag2Cr2 rhomboids along the b-axis [involving Cr(3) and Ag(2) atoms] (Fig. 4), and across four [Cr(1)(dpa)(ox)2]− anionic pillars along the a-axis (Fig. 5), leading to a layer growing in the ab-plane.
The largest intralayer silver–silver and chromium–chromium separations are 19.227(4) [Ag(3)⋯Ag(3e)] and 22.121(4) Å [Cr(1)⋯Cr(1e)] (see Table 4).
The shortest interlayer metal⋯metal separation is 5.4668(14)Å [Cr(1)⋯Ag(3f); (f) = −x + 1, −y, −z + 2].

DIV.HEADER: The versatility of the [Cr(AA)(ox)2]− bulding block in designing heterometallic complexes

s.text: As commented in the introduction, the ability of the anionic [Cr(ox)3]3− complex to act as a tris-bidentate ligand through its six outer oxalate–oxygen atoms towards metal ions has allowed the construction of polyfunctional two- and three-dimensional oxalato-bridged bimetallic networks.

The related [Cr(AA)(ox)2]− species, where an oxalate group of the tris(oxalate)chromate(iii) unit has been replaced by a chelating nitrogen donor AA such as 2,2′-bipyridine (bpy), 2,2′-bipyrimidine (bpym), 1,10-phenanthroline (phen), and 2,2′-dipyridylamine (dpa), keeps the inertness of the tris(oxalato)chromate(iii) complex and the good coordinating ability through the four outer oxalate–oxygen atoms apart from the supramolecular interactions associated with the presence of the aromatic heterocyclic AA ligand that it offers.

The topology and dimensionality of the heterometallic complexes arising from the use of [Cr(AA)(ox)2]− as a ligand depend on the nature, charge, oxidation state and preferred stereochemistry of the cation or preformed cationic complexes which are used.
A priori, the reduction of the number of oxalate groups in the coordination sphere of the precursor [three in [Cr(ox)3]3− and two in [Cr(AA)(ox)2]−] would lead to lower dimensionality compounds.
Let us outline the results obtained with the use of [Cr(AA)(ox)2]− as a ligand.
First of all, the nature (organic or inorganic) of the univalent cation used to neutralize the negative charge of the chromium precursor is a crucial point.

So, ionic salts containing discrete [Cr(AA)(ox)2]− anions are formed when non-coordinating organic cations EX4+ with E = N (X = alkyl group), P and As (X = aryl group), monoprotonated organic bases such as 4-aminopyridinium and Hdpa+ and even cationic radicals such as 2-(4-N-methylpyridinium)-4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-4,5-dihydro-1H-imidazol -1-oxyl-3-N-oxide are used as counterions.
Concerted multiple aryl embraces between the EX4+ cations and graphite-like interactions between the AA groups are observed in the crystal lattice of these ionic salts.
The use of alkaline cations (Na+, K+) afforded neutral two-dimensional networks where the [Cr(AA)(ox)2]− unit (AA = phen, bpy) adopts the different coordination modes shown in Scheme 1.
The values of the Cr–M distance through bridging oxalate vary in the ranges 5.812–6.125 Å [M = K, AA = phen], 5.560–5.865 Å [M = Na, AA = phen] and 5.579(2)–5.672(3) Å [M = Na, AA = bpy].

In the sodium family, the layered structures are made up of oxalate-bridged CrIII–NaI helical chains which are interconnected through [Na(µ-O(ox))2Na] pillars [the sodium–sodium separation being 3.643(8) Å and 3.497(4)–3.534(3) Å for the phen and bpy cases, respectively].

Within each layer, four Cr4Na4 rings and four Cr2Na2 rhomboids alternate regularly around each Cr4Na4 ring with a two-fold (bpy) or four-fold (phen) axes passing through the middle point between two opposite chromium atoms.
The stacking of the neutral layers gives rise to channels of octanuclear Cr4Na4 rings which are filled by AA ligands.
Weak graphite-like interactions between the AA ligands are observed only in the bpy case [mean bpy–bpy and phen–phen interplanar separations are 3.5(1) and 5.0 Å, respectively].
In the case of the potassium example, the two K atoms forming the pillar [the K⋯K separation being 3.3939(9) Å] are connected by four oxalato groups towards four different Cr atoms.
The eight bridging K⋯Cr units form a four-tipped star around the K⋯K pillars.
With alkaline earth cations (MII), the [Cr(AA)(ox)2]− unit (AA = bpy, dpa) acts as bidentate/monodentate (M = Ba), bis-bidentate/bis-monodentate (M = Ba) and bis-bidentate (M = Sr) ligand (Scheme 2).
The self-assembling of the [Cr(AA)(ox)2]− building block with MII affords 3-D (M = Ba, AA = bipy) and 1-D (M = Sr, AA = dpa) complexes.
The barium complex (bpy) is a scaffolding-like material.
The complexity of this structure can be explained on the basis of the three different coordination modes of the oxalate groups and of the high coordination number (ten) of the barium cations.
Two crystallographically independent chromium atoms [Cr(1) and Cr(2)] coexist in this structure.
Each barium is linked to two Cr(1) units, forming thus a 2-D chicken wire motif [the Ba⋯Cr(1) separations being 5.974 and 6.236 Å].
The layers are connected to each other through Ba⋯Ba pillars [the Ba⋯Ba separation being 4.138(3) Å].

The two Ba atoms forming the pillar are connected by four oxalato groups arising from four Cr(2) units which form a four tipped-stars around the Ba⋯Ba pillars [the Ba⋯Cr(2) separation varies in the range 6.132–6.587 Å].
The [Cr(dpa)(ox)2]− unit acts as a bis-bidentate ligand through its two oxalate groups towards the strontium atom, affording a heterobimetallic zig–zag chain.

Each chain is formed by diamond-shaped units which share the Sr atoms, while two crystallographically independent chromium atoms (with different chirality) occupy the remaining two other corners of the unit.
The intrachain Cr–Sr separations are 5.925(3) and 5.962(3) Å.
Adjacent chains are related by an inversion centre leading to an achiral arrangement.
The dpa ligands are located outsite the chain and the interchain π–π interactions are very weak (the shortest separation between pyridyl rings being ca.

Using divalent transition metal ions [M(ii) = Cu(ii), Mn(ii), Co(ii)] the [Cr(AA)(ox)2]− unit (AA = bpy) accomplishes different coordination functions (Scheme 3a), acting as a terminal (bidentate towards Cu, Co) or bridging (bis-bidentate towards Mn) ligand.

The self-assembling of [Cr(bpy)(ox)2]− and MII affords trinuclear Cr2M species (M = Cu, Co) and Cr2M chains (M = Mn), where the oxalate groups connecting the chromium and divalent transition metal ions adopt always the bis-bidentate coordination mode.
The Cr–M separation across oxalato is 5.288 Å for M = Cu and Co and it varies in the range 5.533–5.573 Å for M = Mn.
The Cu(ii) and Co(ii) containing complexes are centrosymmetric.
The Cr2Mn chains are formed by diamond-shaped units sharing the manganese atoms, while the other two corners are occupied by chromium atoms having the same chirality.
The presence of an AA ligand in the coordination sphere of the MII ion has a strong influence on the nature and nuclearity of the resulting compound (see Scheme 3b).

So, for [M(bpy)]2+ (M = Mn and Cu), neutral tetranuclear species of formulae {[Cr(phen)(ox)2]2 [Mn2(bpy)2(H2O)2(ox)]}·6H2O and {[Cr(bpy)(ox)2]2 [Cu2(bpy)2(ox)]}·2H2O are obtained where the [Cr(phen)(ox)2]− unit acts as a monodentate (M = Mn) or bidentate (M = Cu) ligand through one of its two oxalate groups [the Cr⋯M separations across the oxalato bridge are 5.502(5) and 5.507(5) Å (M = Mn) and 5.4473(17) Å (M = Cu)].

The reaction of [Cr(AA)(ox)2]− (AA = bpy and phen) with [Cu(bpca)]+ [bpca = bis(2-pyridylcarbonyl)amide anion], yields the neutral heterodinuclear units of formulae {[Cr(AA)(ox)2][Cu(bpca)(H2O)]}·nH2O [AA = bpy (n = 2.5) and phen (n = 2)] where the [Cr(AA)(ox)2]− unit acts as a bidentate ligand through one of the two oxalate groups.
The Cr⋯Cu separations across bridging oxalato are 5.283(1) Å (bpy) and 5.407(1) Å (phen).
The self-assembling of [Cr(AA)(ox)2]− unit (AA = bpy and dpa) and Ag+ affords very different structural motifs, depending on the N-donor used (Scheme 4).

For AA = bpy, the chromium unit adopts bidentate (through one oxalate ligand) and monodentate (through the other oxalate group) coordination modes (Scheme 4a), forming a discrete neutral (CrAg)2 tetranuclear metallocycle with Cr–Ag separations of 3.841 and 3.886 Å [through bidentate/monodentate (inner) oxalato] and 5.749 and 5.719 Å (through bis-bidentate oxalato).

In the layered structure of 1, the oxalate groups bridge the chromium and silver atoms in five different coordination modes (Scheme 4b): bis-bidenate/monodentate (outer) and bidentate/bis-monodentate [Cr(1)], bis-bidentate [Cr(2)] and bidentate/monodentate (outer) and bis-bidentate/monodentate (inner) [Cr(3)].

This variety of coordination modes of oxalate was never observed in the other bimetallic complexes with the [Cr(AA)(ox)2]− precursor [(AA) = bpy, phen] and it is at the origin of the structural complexity of 1.
When a potential bis-bidentate ligand such as bpym is used in the chromium precursor (see Scheme 5), different layered structures are obtained with alkaline cations (Na+, K+).

In the case of the univalent sodium, an infinite hexagonal array with regular alternating chromium and sodium atoms bridged by bis-bidentate oxalato and bpym (Scheme 5a) is formed (the Cr⋯Na distances are 6.025(3) and 5.618(2) Å through bridging bpym and oxalato, respectively).

However, in the case of the univalent potassium, the bpym and one of the two oxalate groups of the precursor exhibit the bis-bidentate coordination mode but the other oxalate adopts the bis-bidentate/monodentate (outer) bridging mode (Scheme 5b).
Intrasheet tetragonal Cr2K2 motifs occur here in contrast to the octagonal Cr4K4 motifs which are present in the related [KCr(phen)(ox)2(dmf)]·1/2H2O (dmf = dimethylformamide) (see Scheme 1).

An unexpected result is obtained when reacting [Cr(bpym)(ox)2]− with Ag+: the release of bpym and subsequent aquation of the chromium precursor leads to the formation of the mononuclear [Cr(ox)2(H2O)2]− species and the bpym-bridged [Ag(bpym)]nn+ chain (Scheme 5c) which constitute the compound [Ag(bpym)][Cr(ox)2(H2O)2]·2H2O.
This loss of the inert character of the [Cr(bpym)(ox)2]− unit was never observed in the reactions with the parent [Cr(AA)(ox)2]− precursors.

To conclude, we have shown in this work that the use of [Cr(AA)(ox)2]− as a ligand towards fully solvated metal ions or preformed complexes which are coordinatively unsaturated, has afforded a plethora of new heterometallic low dimensional compounds whose structures have been discussed and compared here.
The crystal engineering with this building block is just at the beginning.

High stability, good complexing ability and easy chemical modification of the chromium precursor, allow us to predict that new polyfunctional materials having, for instance, light sensitivity, chirality, and magnetic properties could be prepared in the very near future.
CCDC reference number 224289.
See http://www.rsc.org/suppdata/ce/b3/b314686c/ for crystallographic data in CIF or other electronic format.
